Thanks so much for getting into the cycle issues regarding start up, and  pump cooling.  Internal combustion engines recirculate exhaust gas into the fuel mix to lower combustion temperatures.  The exhaust gas is neutral to the mix, but adds volume, which cools the combustion temp by 500 degrees F, so I was wondering if Firefly could be introducing liquid nitrogen into the main burn mix to keep from melting down the pump.  Thanks to your other videos about the different engine cycle types this is a lot more fun to follow.  Thanks again!!!

Perhaps the fuel delivery to one of the engines failed, reducing thrust and began blowing fuel overboard.

I'm not that familiar with the design, but it appeared as if there was hull distortion and movement you would not expect in that main image looking down the side of the hull towards the bottom edge near the engines. I saw what I thought (hoped) might be some sort of flexible or purposely articulating skirting. But maybe it was not intended to be flexible but indicated a partial structural failure of the Engine Bay, which would have predictably got worse around Max Q, and potentially compromised a fuel cell at some point. If this was structural, that is a huge problem with the design, not insurmountable, but it means they need to go thicker, or with more re-enforcement, which means more weight and less payload. Carbon Fiber is the Gold Standard of lightness and strength when it is enough, but when it is not, it can fail spectacularly. I do believe based on what I have seen that this was a structural failure, and not a rocket engine or fueling failure. Unless it can be explained, there was movement of the geometry of the bottom end of the hull. A tear or weak point?  Databyter
